title: How to Clean Slate

steps.headline: Sweep or remove dust and debris regularly.
steps.description: If you have slate floors, it is important to sweep daily or several times a week. Dust can damage slate over time by wearing away the surface. Keeping a regular cleaning schedule can prevent this damage. Use a dry broom or cloth for this step.

steps.headline: Mix a solution of mild soap and water.
steps.description: For this, you will need a large bucket full of warm water. Mix in a little bit of soap. Dish soap works well for this.

steps.headline: Mop or wipe the surface.
steps.description: Gently wipe the surface of the slate using small circular motions. This motion will loosen and lift dried-on dust and dirt. Use a soft mop, made from materials such as a microfiber. Stiff bristles can damage the stone. For vertical surfaces, clean from the bottom up. Slate should be cleaned with soap every 2-3 months.

steps.headline: Rinse the slate with water.
steps.description: Rinse out your bucket and mop first, and then use them to rinse the slate with water. Soap buildup can attract more dirt, meaning you will have to clean your slate again.

steps.headline: Dry the slate with a fresh, dry, soft cloth.
steps.description: This will remove any streaks from forming on the slate that may occur from air drying and prevent slipping on floor surfaces.

steps.headline: Sweep and mop the slate.
steps.description: Start with removing dry dust and debris by sweeping. Then mop or wipe the slate surface with a soft cloth or microfiber mop in soapy water. Allow the surface to dry.

steps.headline: Apply teak oil to the slate.
steps.description: After the surface is completely dry, apply teak oil to a clean, dry cloth. Using small, circular motions, apply cloth to the slate to cover it in a thin layer of teak oil. Designated slate oil is also available to buy at some hardware stores. However, it tends to be more expensive. Teak oil will achieve the same results.

steps.headline: Clean grout between slate tiles.
steps.description: Mix a solution in a spray bottle that is 50% hydrogen peroxide and 50% water. You can find hydrogen peroxide at hardware stores or pharmacies. Spray the solution onto the grout. Avoid direct contact with the eyes when using hydrogen peroxide. Repeat this step as needed if the grout doesn't look clean after the first round.

steps.headline: Reapply sealant as needed.
steps.description: Sealant protects slate from some everyday wear and tear, and is used on interior surfaces. Each sealant is different, so be sure to follow the specific instructions that come with it. In general, apply at least two layers and allow the sealant to dry completely between coats. Each sealant will come with instructions about how often to reapply it.

steps.headline: Mix a solution in a spray bottle that is 50% hydrogen peroxide and 50% water.
steps.description: Allow the mixture to sit for around 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Spray the solution onto the stain and scrub.
steps.description: Using a soft-bristled brush or microfiber cloth, scrub the stain with small, circular motions. If the stain does not come out, a stronger solution may be needed.

steps.headline: Mix a solution of hydrogen peroxide and baking soda.
steps.description: Add a few spoonfuls of baking soda to the peroxide until the mixture becomes bubbly. Wait until the bubbles stop.

steps.headline: Apply the solution to the stain.
steps.description: Once the peroxide and baking soda mix has set, you can wipe it away with a clean cloth.

Each sealant will come with instructions about how often to reapply it. Removing a Stain Mix a solution in a spray bottle that is 50% hydrogen peroxide and 50% water.
